feed.title: Warning: Usher and Diplo's New Song Will Make You Pregnant

content.div:
When the world's maternity wards are packed to capacity this November, you might as well blame Valentine's Day for the baby boom. But Usher knows thereâ€™s a stronger aphrodisiac than a Loblaw's bouquet and a heart-shaped pepperoni special at the local BP's: Usher, himself.

As such, gird your loins and cover your laptop with some form of contraceptive foam, gel or lead-plated chastity belt. We've got Usher's newest song, "Climax" -- a woozy, R&B jam that could make The Weeknd jealous (and pregnant). Because as producer Diplo himself Tweeted after sharing the track, "I'm pretty sure in 9 months there are gonna be a lot of new babies that this song is responsible for."

Yes, Diplo -- the Grammy nominated DJ and one half of Major Lazer. Usher's last album, 2010's Raymond v. Raymond, found the R&B crooner experimenting with the Eurodance sounds that have more or less dominated the radio ever since. The electronic element of "Climax," however, is more trip-hop textural than fist-pumping -- and as Diplo wrote on Twitter, it's "seriously the best record ive been part of."

(He also described it as being "like radiohead quietstorm," so take from that what you will.)

According to Twitter, Diplo, producer Ariel Rechshaid (Plain White Tees, Glasser) and performer/songwriter Redd Stylez co-wrote the track, which also includes strings by Grizzly Bear/Bjork/Jonsi arranger Nico Muhly.

No word whether "Climax" will appear on a forthcoming Usher record.

Listen to it below:

leahc@dose.ca

entry.title: 2012 Grammy Awards - Best and Worst Moments

link.Abstract: It's music's biggest -- and longest -- night. Adele, Foo Fighters, Whitney Houston and more made for some of the most memorable moments of the 54th Annual Grammy Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. Typically, though, they're in the audience -- collecting more trophies than their Versace-clad arms can carry. That was certainly true of Sunday's edition -- with the likes of Adele, Kanye West and the Foo Fighters being lauded. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evening, but that didn't stop the 54th Annual Grammy Awards from being the marathon, three and a half hour party it always is. Check out some of the highlights.
--Leah Collins/Dose.ca
link.title: As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars.
